body: I manually applied this change to my source and it made absolutely no difference.  The problem continues.
Then you don't have the same problem.
Have not heard anything... should I open this as new issue?
No, it's not designed to work like you want it to.

The documentation says "The Form Validation class supports the use of arrays of field names."

I tested the examples in accordance with the documentation and they have the same problem.

http://www.codeigniter.com/user_guide/libraries/form_validation.html

In version 2.2.2 it did not happen, what is the reason for this be happening?

> No, it's not designed to work like you want it to.

Then it's not designed to work the same as it did in CI version 2.

Uploaded my demo code to a CI v 2.2.0 installation, and verified that it's working perfectly fine.

I simply want it to work consistently whether the input is named `foo` or `foo[1]`, which is the same as it did before v3.

Please re-open this issue.  Thanks.

Without thinking too much (there is no time) I copy/pasted the method form CI2.2
protected function _reduce_array($array, $keys, $i = 0)
in the same place in CI3 and "foo[1]" case started working for me.

>  Would it really make sense to you if 'foo' and 'foo[1]' were the same thing?

Of course not, and I never said these two different names were the same thing.

issue.title: set_value default not working as expected

repository.name: CodeIgniter
repository.description: Open Source PHP Framework (originally from EllisLab)

issue.body:
Latest CI3 release.

The `name` from `object` is used as the field value when submitting an empty value. If you submit an empty value, the field should be empty and not use the default.

`<?php echo set_value('name', $object->name);`
